Situation1: A patient with a chronic autoimmune disease requires a very specific and ongoing treatment plan.
Situation2: This morning is the voter’s only chance to grab a valid ID from home, though the polls remain open tomorrow.
Story:
I glance at the clock on the clinic wall, my mind racing. My patient, Mrs. Lee, sits across from me, her hands trembling as she describes her worsening symptoms. She needs her medication adjusted today—her condition is delicate, and any delay could mean a dangerous flare-up. I know I should take the time to review her chart thoroughly, consult with her specialist, and ensure she leaves with the right prescription and a clear plan.

But I can’t ignore the other voice in my head. Today is the only morning I can get home to pick up my valid ID for voting. If I don’t, I’ll miss my chance to participate in tomorrow’s election—something I believe is my civic duty. The expectation is clear: I must be prepared, responsible, and present as a voter, just as I am as a doctor.

My chest tightens as I weigh the urgency of Mrs. Lee’s care against the narrow window to fulfill my responsibility as a citizen. Both roles demand my full attention, but I can’t be in two places at once. I feel the pressure mounting, torn between the needs of my patient and the call to cast my vote.
